column8: Poetry in Stone.  A beautiful monument in the heart of Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka.
column11: One of the main reasons I include Polonnaruwa in the itinerary of a Sri Lankan Holiday is to visit the ancient carvings of Lord Buddha at Gal Vihara, Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka. It is believed that , during war times, the entire complex was covered in sand to protect it from marauding  enemy armies. The intricately carved statutes of Lord Buddha ( which is disputed by some learned pundits) is a visual treat for the eyes. The monument is now provided with a roof to protect it from the elements. However, it is disheartening to see  one of the forearm of the reclining Buddha statue has been broken. It is suggested that a separate manned shoe stand may be provided for the convenience of the pilgrims and the visitors at Gal Vihara entrance. A must visit while you are in Sri Lanka. Highly recommended.

Gal Viharaya was one of the absolute highlights of my trip to Polonnaruwa—and honestly, to all of Sri Lanka. It’s hard to describe how impressive this place is until you’re standing in front of it. The site features four massive Buddha statues, all carved directly into a single granite rock face over 800 years ago. There’s a reclining Buddha, a seated Buddha, and a standing Buddha—each one full of delicate details. The size and serenity of the statues left me speechless. Even though they’re so big, there’s such a calm, peaceful energy here. It felt like time slowed down while I stood there, taking it all in. I noticed that parts of the carvings are still incredibly sharp, while other areas have softened a bit with time. It’s amazing how skilled the artists were so many centuries ago. Gal Viharaya is definitely a must-see if you’re in Polonnaruwa. It’s not just a historical site—it’s a place that touches your soul. Tip: Go early in the day for softer light, fewer people, and a more peaceful experience.

Welcome to Gal Viharaya, one of the most awe-inspiring sites in Polonnaruwa and a true masterpiece of ancient Sri Lankan stone carving. As your guide, I’m excited to share the fascinating history and spiritual significance of this remarkable site. Gal Viharaya, built by King Parakramabahu the Great in the 12th century, is renowned for its four beautifully crafted Buddha statues, all carved out of a single granite rock face. Each statue represents a different posture of the Buddha—standing, seated, and reclining—offering visitors a profound spiritual experience. First, let’s admire the seated Buddha, placed in deep meditation. The detail in the carving, particularly in the robe's folds and the serene expression on the Buddha’s face, reflects the artistic mastery of the time. Moving on, the standing Buddha is unique, with its arms crossed over the chest, symbolizing deep sorrow or contemplation. This posture is not commonly seen in other Buddha statues, making it especially intriguing. The most iconic statue here is the reclining Buddha, which represents the Buddha’s passing into Nirvana. The calm and peaceful expression on the Buddha’s face, along with the finely carved features of the body, showcase the skill and devotion of the ancient artisans. Notice how the pillow beneath the Buddha’s head is delicately crafted to appear soft, with indentations from the weight of the head—a remarkable detail carved entirely in stone. What makes Gal Viharaya so special is not just the artistic brilliance but also the peaceful, spiritual atmosphere of the site. Surrounded by the ancient ruins of Polonnaruwa, the statues evoke a sense of timelessness and reverence, making this a truly immersive experience for visitors. As we explore these statues, I encourage you to take in not only their beauty but also the deep sense of tranquility that surrounds them. For those interested in history, art, or spirituality, Gal Viharaya is a must-visit destination, offering a glimpse into the skill and devotion of Sri Lanka’s ancient craftsmen. I hope this visit leaves you with a deep appreciation for the incredible history and cultural heritage of Sri Lanka!

The Gal Vihara, and originally as the Uttararama, is a rock temple of the Buddha. It was fashioned in the 12th century by Parakramabahu I. The central feature of the temple is four rock relief statues of the Buddha, which have been carved into the face of a large granitic (granite gneiss) rock. These are some of the best examples of ancient Sinhalese sculpting and carving arts and have made the Gal Vihara the most visited monument at Polonnaruwa.

A rock temple of the Buddha situated in the ancient city of Polonnaruwa in North Central Province, Sri Lanka. It was fashioned in the 12th century by Parakramabahu I. The central feature of the temple is four rock relief statues of the Buddha, which have been carved into the face of a large granite rock. The images consist of a large seated figure, another smaller seated figure inside an artificial cavern, a standing figure and a reclining figure. Our guide explained the 4 carved statues represent the 4 stages of Buddha. First statue on the left represents Buddha achieving enlightenment, second statue is in a seated position representing Buddha preaching, third statue is a standing Buddha contemplating suffering and the final one in reclining position represent Buddha in deathbed.

The Gal Vihara is one of the most important Buddhist sites situated in the ancient Sri Lankan capital of Polonnaruwa.  The site itself is located in a picturesque and peaceful corner of the vast Polonnaruwa ruins, reached after you have toured the other temples and stupas on the site. Despite the crowds of visitors, it is at once intensely serene and peaceful,  and one can see why this spot was chosen to carve into the living rock  three representations of the Lord Buddha - one sitting, one standing , and one lying down. Of these three however, the most intriguing is the standing Buddha,  which for some strange (and still today unexplained) reason, has his hands crossed on his chest in a very non-Buddhist fashion, more akin to the pose adopted  by the ancient Egyptians in their mummified form..... it's a complete mystery why this pose was adopted, and is, I think, unique in Buddhist idolatry. Intriguing or what?....   (Top tip - Despite the site being from the 12th century, it is still regarded as "holy", so you must remove your shoes to visit.  The ground is sandy with small pebbles - come prepared!)

The Gal Vihara (Sinhalese: ගල් විහාරය), also known as Gal Viharaya and originally as the Uttararama, is a rock temple of the Buddha situated in the ancient city of Polonnaruwa in North Central Province, Sri Lanka. It was fashioned in the 12th century by Parakramabahu I. The central feature of the temple is four rock relief statues of the Buddha, which have been carved into the face of a large granite rock. The images consist of a large seated figure, another smaller seated figure inside an artificial cavern, a standing figure and a reclining figure. These are considered to be some of the best examples of ancient Sinhalese sculpting and carving arts, and have made the Gal Vihara the most visited monument at Polonnaruwa.

Gal Vihara (Sinhala: stone temple), Buddhist Temple at (UNESCO World Heritage Site) at Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka is the most perfect specimen of Buddha statue hewn out of solid stone. Crafted during the reign of King Parakrabahu (1153-1186 A.C), Gal Vihara statues are still in complete preservation with their irresistible charm and sublimity. It is undeniable that the sculptors of Gal Vihara were of greater skill and expertise in the art of stone sculpture in Sri Lanka. The images at Gal Vihara have brought about higher level of awakening in the observers with respect of Buddhist art in Sri Lanka. Gal Vihara at Polonnaruwa in Sri Lanka known as “The Northern Temple” in the beginning of its history, is a cave complex, about 27 meters in length and 10 meters in height at the centre and sloping towards the ends, with sculptures carved on the solid rock in four shrines. Gal Vihara, like numerous other Buddhist shrines of Sri Lanka, is a shrine of Theravada Buddhism. Then again Gal Vihara testifies to the influence of Mahayana Buddhism during the 12th century. Caves of Gal Vihara Gal Vihara consists of four cave shrines with sculptures hallowed out of a granite rock.Caves from left to right are (a) Cave of Vijjadharas, (b) Excavated Cave, (c) Cave of Standing Image and (d) Cave of Reclining Image. Between the Excavated Cave and the Cave of Standing Image is an inscription. In front of the Excavated Cave are remains of a pavilion. Though the brick walls of the four shrines had collapsed centuries ago, the foundations remain giving evidence that each statue was separated from one another. Cave of Vijjadharas The cave consists of a main image of Buddha sculpted out of the rock boulder, having carved round and four small bas relief carvings of Buddha. The small bas relief statues are carved on either sides, above the head of the main image. The main image depicts the chief of meditative Buddhas titled Dharmadhatu, Adi Buddha, Vairocana and Vajrasattva. The four small images of the Buddha in Dhayani Mudra represent the four directions of the universe. All five images are of Dhyana Mudra or meditative posture is believed to depict the all embracing Body of Law (Dharmakaya). The Excavated Cave The Excavated cave too houses an image of Buddha in dhayana mudra or meditative attitude sculpted out of the rock boulder. The image herein is smaller than the main image at Vijjadhara Cave. The Cave of Standing Image The Buddha statue rising to 7 meters in height herein, stands on a lotus pedestal called Padmasana. Padmasana signifies that Buddha is a transcendental being. The Cave of Standing image: Ananda or Buddha The standing statue is at the head of the massive reclining Buddha. The standing statue’s placing of arms across the breast has caused a controversy as to the identity of the statue. The early archeologists believed the statue was that of Ananda, an attendant disciple of Buddha grieving at the passing away of Buddha. However, the subsequent studies at Gal Vihara on the features of the statue have established that the standing image is that of Buddha and not of his disciple Ananda. Firstly, since the standing image was once contained in its own shrine room, separated by brick walls it has no relevance to the reclining image. Though the brick walls of the three caves had collapsed several centuries ago, the foundations can still be seen. Secondly, the right-ward curled clusters of hair are only found on the images of the Buddha and not on the images of his disciples in the same period. Thirdly, the Buddhist artists never offered the Lotus throne or Padmasana to disciples Fourthly, the ears of the statue herein are elongated. Of all the statues of Buddha, his disciples and deities, only the images of Buddhas consist of elongated ears.

Reached along a good quality path, your ticket will be inspected shortly before you reach the Buddhas and the appropriate stub, one of three, torn out. The area before the Buddhas, one upright and the larger and more impressive lying down, is roped off. The ground is loose coarse sand and grit and visitors can only approach closely by removing hats and footware, though a reasonable photo can be obtained without entering the roped off area. As usual you should refrain from photographing friends, family or even yourself with back to the Buddhas. If you want to appear in the photograph without showing disrespect the best way to do so it to stand before the Buddha bur side on to it looking towards the camera. To the left as you face the statues is a large seated Buddha with a smaller shrine in the centre with a seated Buddha within. To the left of the standing figure take note of the apparently smooth and slightly inclined rock face. This bears a lengthy original inscription best seen in the oblique light of late afternoon when the site as a whole is cooler and less busy. Nearby as you leave the foundations of a small hall are visible and the paths nearby offer the chance of a pleasant short walk around the water seen as you approached from the road. Gal Vihara is an impressive site, often one of the final locations visited on the 'ruins trail' at Polonnaruwa but will only need around 15 minutes at the remains themselves unless you have a specific interest.

Admire the true talents of ancient artists.... This is the only (as per my knowledge) place with Buddha statues surviving unharmed in this erea. You need to travel couple of minutes away from main historical place. But still worth the journey.

This is absolutely sublime, for me the finest examples of Buddha rupas anywhere.  Cut into a sheer granite cliff, one seated, one standing (with unusual crossed arms mudra) and one recumbent, all with beautifully enigmatic faces.  There is a local legend amongst the Sinhalese that a white man once stood on the cliff opposite the recumbent statue and took a pot shot at it with a gun just to see if anything would come of it.  Then when he walked away, he was followed into the forest and killed by an elephant.  Two footprints carved into the cliff from where he took the shot at the Buddha rupa can still be found to mark this legend.  Highly highly recommended.

A short walk down a path from the road through Polonnuwara site Gal Vihara is an large granite outcrop out of which four statues have been carved. Three are definitely of Buddha; they are massive and beautifully carved. If you enter the site itself (it is a sacred place so take your shoes off) you can get quite close and see the exquisite detail in the carving. This is in my view best on the reclining statue where the marbling effect of the rock is fantastic. This particular statue is superb. Our Buddhist guide told us to look for the position of the feet. If the toes are even this shows Buddha resting. The one at Gal Vihara has the toes of one foot slightly forward which denotes the statue represents Buddha at the time of his death and entering Nirvana. The facial expressions on these statues are simple but like nothing else I've seen. Yes, there are some barriers and a canopy. They don't spoil the place, it needs protecting and it is sacred to Buddhists. Two points to note - the ground in front of the statues gets extremely hot. Socks would be an idea. The place is also frequented by two types of monkey who are used to humans and unfortunately expect to be fed by them. The macaques in particular can get aggressive so be careful. The other types are langurs which are light coloured with dark faces.

For me, this site alone was worth the entry fee into the Polonnaruwa complex. There are 4 magnificent Buddhas carved out of a single solid rock. They are all in exquisite condition. The statues are sheltered with permanent canopies providing shade to protect visitors from the intense sun.

This area of Polonnaruwa is so beautiful large stone Buddhas carved out of the natural rock.  One can only stand in awe of the dedicated stone masons who created these monuments so long ago. They are in remarkably wonderful condition and are guardians to the beautiful temple areas.  This was my second time there, and I never tire of viewing these holy places.

In one small area are these imposing Buddha statues. Forming part of a rock temple, all have been carved out of the granite. Indeed the type of statue appears to have been chosen to fit the space and shape of the rock formation. These were carved in the 12th century. Dominating all is the Buddha attaining nirvana, often described as sleeping. It is reclining and about 14 metres in length. This makes it one of the largest in SE Asia as well. One image rests inside a small niche and is the smallest. To its left (facing) is an image seated on a throne. This has additional carvings around the main image of Buddhas within small niches. In addition there are lions and lotus flowers. The standing image may not be an image of  Buddha. Our guide informed us that there is a view that it is of his disciple, Ananda. Nearby the code to be observed by the abbots is written in modern form. The actual code is inscribed on the rock face adjacent to the standing image. As it is a holy site shoes and hats are not permitted. Wear socks as the sand gets very hot indeed.

This is very cool.  The three statues of Buddha (siting, standing and laying down) all from a single rock.  Very good.

The Buddha statues are carved in stone and they depict the virtues of Buddha perfectly well despite the fact that the statues are made of stone. The name "gal vihara" means stone temple. Probably this name has been given to this place because everything has been done with or on stones. It is such a beautiful place to visit to see the talents of ancient sinhalese artists. This is also a good way of understanding the reverence that the Sri Lankans have towards Lord Buddha and his teachings. All these things have been done during the times of the ancient kings of Sri Lanka. From those days there has been a rule of governance stating that the King who rules the country should give the foremost place to Buddhism as it is believed that Lord Buddha visited the country thrice during his lifetime in order to help people solve their problems. This is probably the reason why the Sri Lankan constitution also states that the foremost place should be given to Buddhism. But this has in no way been used to undermine the other religions. It is better if foreigners visit this place in the early hours of the morning or after 3 p.m. That is because this place gets really hot during the midday and some people find it really difficult to walk in this place without their footwear. You will have to take your footwear off because it is a religious place and it is believed to be a sign of disrespect if you wear shoes or slippers. I cannot remember whether you have to be in long white clothes to go to this place but I think it would be better if you go to this place wearing decent clothes. I would advise foreigners who want to visit this place to avoid this place during midday unless you want to have blisters on your feet.

Constructed in the 12th century by King Parakramabahu the Great, this comprise of 4 Buddha statues carved out of granite rock. They differ in size and the largest is more than 46 feet long. Take time to talk to the old gentleman who is ever willing to explain the history about the statues and also to sit on the large rock opposite the Gal Vihare and just look at it quietly.
